item1_summary:
The regulatory environment to which we are subject is discussed in "Item 1 - Business" beginning on page  revenue and business strategy . A majority of our revenue is derived from clearing and transaction fees, which include electronic trading fees, surcharges for privately negotiated transactions and other volume-related charges for exchange-traded and over-the-counter contracts .
 Volume has the most significant impact on clearing and transaction fees revenue . Rate structure, product mix and revenue also influence this source of revenue . The percentage of trades executed by customers who are members compared with non-member customers . Rates are varied by product in order to optimize revenue on existing products and to encourage contract volume upon introduction of new products .
 BrokerTec Americas provides matching services to allow both parties to complete the trade bilaterally or through a third-party clearing house . Revenue is generated from this business generally on a transaction fee basis . Revenue decreases if the percentage of trades executed by members increases . Revenue also derived from other sources, including market data and information services .
 Our service offerings include access to real-time, delayed and end-of-day quotations, trade and summary market data for our products and other data sources . Users of our basic service receive real time quotes and pay a flat monthly fee for each screen, or device, displaying our market data . Alternatively, customers can subscribe to market data provided on a limited group of products .
 The majority of our expenses do not vary directly with changes in contract volume . Licensing and other fee agreements can vary with certain equity, energy and swap volumes . Compensation and benefits expense is our most significant expense . Changes in this expense are driven by fluctuations in the number of employees, increases in wages as a result of labor market conditions, changes in rates for employer taxes .
 Depreciation and amortization expense results from the depreciation of long-lived assets such as buildings, leasehold improvements, furniture, fixtures and equipment . Technology expense consists of costs related to maintenance of the hardware and software required to support our technology. Technology expense also includes costs for network connections for our electronic platforms and some market data customers .
 Licensing and other fee agreements expense includes license fees paid as a result of contract volume in equity index products . Marketing, advertising and public relations expense includes media, print and other advertising costs . Other expenses include litigation and customer settlements, impairment charges on operating assets, gains and losses on disposals of certain operating assets .
 Investment income is influenced by market interest rates, changes in the levels of cash performance bonds deposited by clearing firms, the amount of dividends distributed by our strategic investments . Losses include income and losses from our investments in S&P Dow Jones Indices LLC, OSTTRA, Shanghai CFETS-NEX International Money Broking Co., Ltd. and Gulf Mercantile Exchange .
 There are certain accounting policies that we consider to be critical . These policies relate to the valuation of financial instruments, goodwill and intangible assets, revenue recognition, income taxes and internal use software costs . Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants .
 Goodwill may be tested quantitatively for impairment by comparing the carrying value of a reporting unit to its estimated fair value . Under certain favorable circumstances, goodwill may be reviewed qualitatively for indications of impairment without utilizing valuation techniques to estimate fair value. The qualitative assessment of goodwill may rely on significant assumptions about forecasts of revenue growth, operating margins and economic conditions .
 Intangible assets subject to amortization are also assessed for impairment on a quarterly basis or more frequently when indicated by a change in economic or operational circumstances . Under certain favorable circumstances, indefinite-lived intangible assets may be reviewed qualitatively for indications of impairment without utilizing valuation techniques to estimate fair value . The impairment assessment of these assets requires management to first compare the carrying value of the amortizing asset to its undiscounted net cash flows .
 A portion of our revenue is derived from the clearing and transaction fees we assess on each contract executed through our trading venues and cleared through our clearing house . We also earn revenue from the dissemination of market data to subscribers, distributors, and other third-party licensees . Calculation of the income tax provision includes an estimate of income taxes that will be paid for the current year .
 If the actual obligation of these amounts varies from our estimate, our income tax provision would be reduced or increased at the time that determination is made . The effective tax rate will vary from year to year based on changes in tax rates and regulations . Software development costs incurred during the planning or maintenance stages of a software project are expensed as incurred .
 The following summarizes significant changes in our financial performance for the years presented . For a comparison of our results of operations for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2023 to December 31, 2022, see "Part II, Item 7 - Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" of our Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC on February 28, 2024 .
 Contract volume and average rate per contract disclosures below exclude trading volume for cash markets business as well as interest rate swaps . We estimate the following net increase in clearing and transaction fees based on a change in total contract volume during 2024 compared with 2023 . Average daily contract volume can be influenced by many factors, including political and economic factors, the regulatory environment and market competition .
 Market volatility within certain financial markets remained high throughout 2024 . Interest rate volatility was higher as a result of mixed inflation levels and market uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy decisions . We believe these factors contributed to the increase in total volume in 2024 compared with 2023 . We also expanded our ongoing sales efforts across many of the product lines to increase sales growth across the globe .
 In 2024 compared with 2023, overall interest rate contract volume increased as a result of general market uncertainty . The Federal Reserve cut interest rates three times in 2024 and issued cautious guidance for 2025 . The increase in Nasdaq-100 contract volume was partially offset by lower overall equity volatility within the S&P 500 .
 The Federal Reserve cut interest rates three times in 2024, but issued cautious guidance moving forward as a result of continued uncertainty surrounding inflation . We believe this is due to uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve and other global central banks' interest rate policy decisions . The following table summarizes average daily volume for our key agricultural commodity products .
 The following table summarizes average daily volume for our key metal products . The average rate per contract was impacted by an increase in our fee structure, which went into effect on February 1, 2024 . The overall increase due to the rise in fees was offset by a decrease resulting from higher member trading as a percentage of total volume .
 The revenue primarily includes transaction fees from BrokerTecs's fixed income volume and EBS foreign exchange volume . ue in 2024 included $276.7 million of transaction fees attributable to the cash markets business, compared with $284.7m in  2023 . The majority of clearing and transaction fees received from clearing firms represent charges for trades executed and cleared on behalf of their customers .
 Approximately 30% of market data and information services revenue in 2024 was earned from the two largest resellers of our market data . The increase in other revenue was largely attributable to higher custody fees as well as an increase in co-location and other connectivity fees . Operating expenses increased by $55.4 million in 2024 when compared with 2023 .
 Operating expenses increased in 2024 when compared with 2023 due to the following reasons . The increase in expenses related to technology support services was primarily driven by higher software license fees and third party services to support the ongoing Google Cloud transformation project . The decrease in professional fees and outside services were largely due to a decrease in consulting costs associated with the Google Cloud Migration, which began in 2021 .
 In 2024 when compared with 2023, there was a decrease in earnings from reinvested cash performance bond and guaranty fund contributions due to lower average reinvestment balances . The overall effective tax rate remained relatively consistent in 2024 . We have historically met our funding requirements with cash generated by our ongoing operations. However, we have used our commercial paper program from time to time to fund large short-term funding needs .
 Our sources of operating cash are largely dependent on contract trading volume levels . Cash will also be required for non-cancellable purchase obligations as at December 31, 2024 . In 2025, we expect capital expenditures to total approximately $90.0 million . Future capital expenditures for technology are anticipated as we continue to support our growth .
 The board of directors approved a share repurchase program, which authorizes us to repurchase up to $3.0 billion of CME Group Class A common stock at prevailing market prices . As of December 31, 2024, there have been no shares repurchased under this program . On February 6, 2025, the company declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.25 per shreare for all outstanding shares .
 The following is a summary of cash flows from operating, investing and financing activities . The increase in cash used in investing activities in 2024 compared with 2023 was due to lower overall proceeds on sales of investments . Cash provided by financing activities was higher in 2024 when compared with 2023 . The following table summarizes our debt outstanding as of December 31, 2024 .
 We maintain a $2.3 billion multi-currency revolving senior credit facility with various financial institutions, which matures in November 2026 . Proceeds from this facility can be used for general corporate purposes, which includes providing liquidity for our clearing house in certain circumstances at CME Group's discretion . We currently do not have any borrowings outstanding under this facility, but any commercial paper balance if or when outstanding can be backed up against this facility .
 The facility provides for borrowings of up to $7.0 billion . We may use the proceeds to provide temporary liquidity in the unlikely event a clearing firm fails to promptly discharge an obligation to the clearing house, in the event of a liquidity constraint or default by a depositary . At December 31, 2024, guaranty fund contributions available to collateralize the facility totaled $10.1 billion .
 CME Group, as a holding company, has no operations of its own . Instead, it relies on dividends declared and paid to it by its subsidiaries in order to provide the funds that it uses to pay dividends to its shareholders . At December 31, 2024, we were in compliance with the various covenant requirements of all our debt facilities .
 Given our cash flow generation, our ability to pay down debt levels, if necessary, we expect to maintain an investment grade rating . Cash and cash equivalents, excluding restricted cash, totaled $2.9 billion at both December 31, 2024 and December 31, 2023 . A majority of our cash and cash . equivalents balance is invested in money market mutual funds that invest only in U.S. Treasury securities . Our exposure to credit and liquidity risk is minimal .
 CME was designated by the Financial Stability Oversight Council as a systemically important financial market utility under Title VIII of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act . CME, CBOT, NYMEX and COMEX are regulated by the CFTC as designated contract markets (DCM) BrokerTec Americas LLC is required to maintain sufficient net capital under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 .
 The firm began operating as a (k)(2)(i) broker-dealer in November 2017 following notification to the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority and the SEC . The firm is exposed to various market risks, including those caused by changes in interest rates, credit and foreign currency exchange rates . CME Clearing House acts as the counterparty to all trades consummated on our exchange as well as through third party exchanges and swaps markets .
 In order to ensure performance, we establish and monitor financial requirements for our clearing firms . We set minimum performance bond requirements for exchange-traded and interest rate swaps products . We mark-to-market open positions of clearing firms at least once a day (twice a day for futures and options contracts) and require payment from clearing firms whose positions have lost value .
 We cannot guarantee that these measures will be sufficient to protect us from a default or that we will not be materially and adversely affected in the event of a significant default . We maintain a $7.0 billion 364-day multi-currency line of credit with a consortium of domestic and international banks to be used in certain situations by our clearing house .
 We also have the option to use our $2.3 billion multi-currency revolving senior credit facility to provide liquidity for our clearing house in the unlikely event of default . Pledged assets may include clearing firm guaranty fund deposits held by us in the form of cash or U.S. Treasury securities . Performance bond collateral of a defaulting clearing firm may also be used to secure a draw on the line .
 Clearing House designates $100.0 million of corporate contributions to satisfy a clearing firm default in the event that the defaulting clearing firm's guaranty contributions and performance bonds do not satisfy the deficit . A defaulting firm's performance bond deposits, non-cash deposits, Interest Earnings Facility funds and letters of credit can be used in default of that clearing firm .
 Clearing House designates $150.0 million of corporate contributions to satisfy a clearing firm default in the event that the defaulting clearing firm's guaranty contributions and performance bonds do not satisfy the deficit . Assessment powers are calculated to reflect the potential obligation that each clearing member could be called for based on potential failure of the third and fourth largest clearing member .
 BrokerTec Americas maintains a matched principal business, where it serves as a fully matched counterparty to offsetting positions entered into by clients on its electronic trading platform . At December 31, 2024, the balance of the collateral at FICC was $230.0 million, which was included in other current assets on the consolidated balance sheet .
 We have foreign currency transaction risk related to changes in exchange rates on monetary assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses held at subsidiaries where those balances and activity are denominated in a currency other than the subsidiary's functional currency . We expect the foreign currency gain/loss to continue to fluctuate as long as we continue to hold monetary assets and liabilities at those subsidiaries .
 A portion of performance bond deposits is denominated in various foreign currencies . We mark-to-market all deposits daily and require payment from clearing firms whose collateral has lost value due to changes in foreign currency rates and price . Aggregate translation gains (losses) for 2024, 2023 and 2022 were $61.0 million, $70.8 million and $195.4 million .
 CME Group's current current liabilities: preferred stock, $0.01 par value, 10,000 shares authorized as of December 31, 2024 and 2023; 4,584 issued and outstanding as of Dec. 31 . Total Liabilities: revenues 6,130.1.1; $102,313.9; $129,706.2; $2,988.2.9.9 in debt; $137,447.0 in other comprehensive income (loss) See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements .
 CME Group's net income is $3,525.8% and $2,691.0% . Earnings per Share Attributable to Common Shareholders are $9.69/€9.87/€8.67/€7.67% . Net income before Income Taxes: $3.5/€3,541.4/€4,153/£3,490/€2,490 . Net earnings (losses) of unconsolidated subsidiaries: $3,500/€1,600/1,800/2,800 . Net net income before income taxes: $1,931/£1,788/£2,932/£4,787/£5,936/4
 CME Group Inc. and SUBSIDIARIES provide financial statements . The Company's financial statements are based on common and preferred stock information . The company paid $8.50 per common share and $3,096.50 for preferred share dividends . The net loss is $2,691.0 per share, net of tax, interest and other comprehensive income (loss)
 CME Group Shareholders' Equity at December 31, 2022: 4,584.584.395,359,231.3$22,265.2$4,746.8$26,878.7$2,737.9$3,795.2% Net income: 3,525.8% - compound income; Dividends of $9.65 per common share and preferred share: $10.40% per share; $1.9% net income: $1.4% net loss: $77.7.7% net profit: $3,226.2%.
 At December 31, 2024, CME Group Inc. rd of Directors had $22,406.3 billion in cash and assets . Cash and non-taxes related to operating activities . Net cash provided by operating activities: $3,690.5 billion; $2,691.2 billion in non-operating expenses; . $3.6 billion in operating expenses; $2,700.0 billion in investments; $1,700,000 in dividends and $1.7 billion in dividends .
 CME Group Inc.  Investing Activities: "Purchased" investing activities: "Investing Activities," "Purchases," "purchased," "borrowed" Cash, cash equivalents, restricted cash and "restricted cash equivalents" CME GROUP INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES: "CME GROUP Inc. and Subsidiaries"
 CME Group Inc. (CME Group) exchanges offer the widest range of global benchmark products across all major asset classes based on interest rates, equity indexes, foreign exchange (FX), agricultural, energy and commodities . CME offers clearing, settlement and guarantees for all products cleared through the clearing house, which is operated by CME .
 Cash and Cash Equivalents consist of cash and highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less at the time of purchase . Trading securities held in connection with non-qualified deferred compensation plans are recorded at fair value, with net realized and unrealized gains and losses and dividend income reported as investment income .
 The company reviews its investment portfolio at least quarterly, as well as whenever facts or circumstances exist which indicate that the carrying value of an investment is greater than its fair value . The fair value of a financial instrument is the amount that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date . Derivative Investments are recorded at fair value on the consolidated balance sheets .
 The company assesses, both at the inception of each hedge and on an ongoing basis, whether the derivative financial instruments that are designated as cash flow hedging transactions are highly effective in offsetting changes in cash flows . Exposure to losses on receivables for clearing and transaction fees and other amounts owed by clearing and trading firms is dependent on each firm's financial condition .
 Interest earned on these investments accrues to CME and is included in investment income on the consolidated statements of income . CME may distribute any interest earned on its investments to the clearing firms at its discretion . Cash performance bonds and guaranty fund contributions are considered restricted cash as the cash deposits cannot be used for the company's operations or to satisfy any operational liabilities .
 Depreciation and amortization are calculated using the straight-line method, generally over one to twenty years . Property and equipment are depreciated over their estimated useful lives . Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the remaining term of the respective lease to which they relate or the remaining useful life of the leasehold improvement .
 Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price over the fair value of the net assets acquired in a business combination . The company reviews goodwill for impairment at least quarterly and whenever events or circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable . If the carrying amount exceeds fair value, an impairment loss is recorded .
 The method requires the carrying value of the assets to be determined at their fair value . If the value exceeds the amount, the amount is then the amount of the amortment is determined . The amount of amortments must be determined by an independent process of evaluating the value of an intangible asset to determine whether it is fair or not .
 Foreign currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities are re-measured into the functional currency using period-end exchange rates . Gains and losses resulting from foreign currency translations are included in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) within shareholders' equity . The majority of our clearing and transaction fees are recognized as  transaction fees .
 Revenue is recognized upon successful execution of the trade, which represents completion of our trade matching, novation and clearing activities . Unfilled or canceled buy and sell orders have no impact on revenue . On occasion, the customer's exchange trading privileges may not be properly entered by the clearing firm and incorrect fees are charged for the transactions .
 The company does not believe that the company is exposed to significant risk from a loss of revenue received from a particular clearing firm . The company recognizes expense relating to stock-based compensation on an accelerated basis . Marketing costs are incurred for the production and communication of advertising as well as other marketing activities. The company accounts for share-based payments at fair value, which is based on the grant date price of the equity awards issued .
 The company reports the results of its operations as one operating segment primarily comprised of the businesses of CME, CBOT, NYMEX, COMEX and our cash markets business . FASB issued final guidance requiring public business entities to provide disclosures of each relevant expense line item on the face of the income statement in continuing operations .
 P are required to be included in the disaggregated income statement expense line item disclosures, and any remaining amounts need to be described qualitatively . The disclosures are effective beginning in 2027, and required on an annual and interim basis . Early adoption is permitted . Adoption of this guidance is not expected to have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements .
 Market data and information services represent revenue from the dissemination of market data to subscribers, distributors, and other third-party licensees . Pricing for market data is primarily based on the number of reportable devices used as well as subscribers enrolled under the arrangement . Other revenues include certain access and communication fees, fees for collateral management, equity membership subscription fees, and fees for trade order routing .
 Management fees are charged to clearing firms that have collateral on deposit with the clearing house to meet their minimum performance bond and guaranty fund obligations on the exchange . This fee revenue is recognized monthly as billed as the customers receive and consume the benefits of the services . The company also has an equity membership program which provides equity members the option to pay a monthly subscription fee in satisfaction of their existing requirement to hold Class A common stock .
 The timing of revenue recognition, billings and cash collections results in billed accounts receivable, and customer advances and deposits (contract liabilities) on the consolidated balance sheets . Certain fees for transactions, annual licenses, and other revenue arrangements are billed upfront before revenue is recognized, which results in recognition of contract liabilities . These liabilities are recognized on a contract-by-contract basis upon commencement of services under the customer contract .
 Each clearing firm is required to deposit and maintain balances in the form of cash, U.S. government securities, certain foreign government securities . All non-cash deposits and certain cash deposits with foreign currency exposure are marked-to-market and haircut on a daily basis . Securities deposited by the clearing firms are not reflected on the consolidated financial statements and the clearing house does not earn any interest on these deposits .
 Under the extremely unlikely scenario of simultaneous default by every clearing firm who has open positions with unrealized losses, the maximum exposure at the time of default related to positions other than interest rate swap contracts would be one half day of changes in fair value of all open positions . The clearing house reduces its exposure through maintenance performance bond requirements and guaranty fund contributions .
 CME has been designated as a systemically important financial market utility by the Financial Stability Oversight Council and is authorized to maintain cash accounts at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago . CME and The Options Clearing Corporation (OCC) have a perpetual cross-margin arrangement . Earnings from cash performance bonds and guaranty fund contributions are included in investment income and the expense related to the distribution of interest earned is included in other non-operating income .
 In the event of a remaining loss, CME would apply assets of the defaulting clearing firm to satisfy its payment obligation . CME has a cross-margin arrangement with Fixed Income Clearing Corporation (FICC) whereby certain of the clearing firms' offsetting positions with CME and FICC are subject to reduced performance bond requirements .
 Each clearing firm for futures and options is required to deposit and maintain specified guaranty fund contributions in the form of cash or U.S. Treasury securities . In the event of a default, CME would first apply assets of the defaulting clearing firm to satisfy its payment obligation . Thereafter, if the payment default remains unsatisfied, the clearing house would use its corporate contributions designated for the respective financial safeguard package .
 CME maintains a multi-currency line of credit with a consortium of domestic and international banks to be used in certain situations by the clearing house . Clearing firm guaranty fund contributions received in the form of cash or U.S. Treasury securities as well as the performance bond assets of a defaulting firm can be used to collateralize the facility .
 The company maintains committed repurchase facility agreements amounting to a total of $1.0 billion . The company also has the option to use the $2.3 billion multi-currency revolving senior credit facility to provide liquidity for the clearing house in the unlikely event of default . CME also maintains a committed facility of up to $750.0 million for foreign currency conversions .
 Cash, securities and letters of credit posted as performance bonds are only available to meet financial obligations of that clearing firm to the clearing house . Letters of credit may be used as performance bond deposits for clearing firms . The balance of intraday settlements was $198198.4 million and $237.5 million at December 31, 2024 and 2023 .
 Amortizable intangible assets consisted of the following at  December 31, 2024 and 2023: Amortable Intangible Assets: Clearing firm, market data and other customer relationships . The originally assigned useful lives for the amortable intangible assets as of December 31, 2024 are as follows: The amortizable intangible assets include trading products acquired in business combinations with CBOT Holdings, Inc., NYMEX Holdings and The Board of Trade of Kansas City .
 The company owns a 33% interest in GME Holdings Limited . Dubai Mercantile Exchange (DME) was rebranded in 2024 to reflect its position as the key regional commodities exchange in the Middle East . The company maintains various long-term investments as described below . The investments are recorded in other assets on the consolidated balance sheets .
 The company owns a 50% equity interest in OSTTRA, which is a joint venture withe IHS Markit . The company has long-term exclusive licensing agreements with S&P Dow Jones Indices LLC to list products based on the Standard & Poor's Indices and Dow Jones . The carrying amount of the company's investment in OstTRA was $1.2 billion at December 31, 2024 .
 The company maintained a forward-starting interest rate swap agreement that modified the interest obligation associated with these notes so that the interest payable on the notes effectively became fixed at a rate of  3.11% . The company is su su su.  The company's short-term and long-term debt maturities, at par value were as follows as of December 31, 2024:
 In 2024, 2023 and 2022, the effective tax rates were higher than the statutory tax rate . The effective tax rate for the state taxes were partially offset by the foreign-derived intangible income (FDII) deduction . At the time of December 31, 2024 and 2023, deferred income tax assets (liabilities) consisted of the following: 
 A valuation allowance is recorded when it is more likely-than-not that some portion or all of the deferred income tax assets may not be realized . At December 31, 2024, the company had domestic income tax loss carryforwards of $25.1 million of which $22.1-million will expire between 2030 and 2036 and $3.0 million can be carried forward indefinitely . These amounts relate to losses from the acquisition of NEX Group plc .
 The company is subject to U.S. federal income tax as well as income taxes in Illinois and multiple other state, local and foreign jurisdictions . CME maintains a non-contributory defined benefit cash balance pension plan for eligible employees . Employees who have completed a continuous 12-month period of employment and have reached the age of  21 are eligible to participate .
 The measurement date used for the plan is December 31. Participants become vested in their accounts after  three years of service . The aggregate accumulated benefit obligation was $.335.6 million an.insured $.323.2 million at December  31, 2024 and 2023, respectively . The fair value of each major category of plan assets as of December  is indicated below .
 CME's funding goal is to have its pension plan 100% funded at each year-end on a projected benefit obligation basis . The amount of the actual contribution is contingent on various factors, including the actual rate of return on the plan assets during 2025 and the December 31, 2025 discount rate . The company anticipates an additional contribution of $12.2 million in 2025 will be necessary for it to meet its funding goal .
 The discount rate for the plan was determined based on the market value of a theoretical settlement bond portfolio . The total return is expected to equal the composite performance of the security markets over the long term . The overall objective of the plan is to achieve required long-term rates of return in order to meet future benefit payments . The asset mix has a minimum and maximum range depending on asset class .
 The company may determine that it is necessary to place some assets in cash equivalent investments in order to pay  expected plan liabilities . The actual asset allocation for the plan may not fall within the target allocation ranges from time to time . If the plan directly invests in short-term and long-term debt obligations, the investments are limited to obligations rated at the highest rating category by Standard & Poor's or Moody's .
 CME maintains a defined contribution savings plan pursuant to Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code . All U.S. employees are participants and have the option to contribute to this plan . CME matches employee contributions up to                 3.3% of the employee's base salary and may make additional discretionary contributions . In addition to the plan, the company maintains plans for employees in international locations .
 The company maintains non-qualified retirement and benefit plans under the COMEX Members' Retirement Plan and Benefits plan . Participation is limited to individuals who were COMEX division members prior to NYMEX's acquisition of COMEX in 1994 . There were no contributions to the plan in 2024, 2023 and 2022 . At December 31, 2024 and 2023, the obligation for the MRRP totaled $7.3.3% and $8.7% .
 Management evaluates the exercisability of these options at least quarterly in order to determine whether the contract term must be reassessed . For certain office spaces, the company has entered into arrangements to sublease excess space to third parties, while the original lease contract remains in effect with the landlord . The company also has one finance lease, which is related to the sale of our datacenter in March 2016 .
 Cash flow information related to leases was as follows for years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023:  Operating leases (in millions) and finance leases (as of December 31, 2024) Cash outflows for operating leases were as follows: $73.7-7.7 (in months) Average remaining lease term was  rewarded in months, with average discount rate of  4.2-3.5% . Future minimum lease payments were  as follows as of Dec. 31, 24, 2024 for operating and finance lease .
 A putative class action complaint was filed January 15, 2014 in the Circuit Court of Cook County, Chancery Division, against CME Group Inc. and the Board of Trade of the City of Chicago, Inc. Plaintiffs allege breach of contract and breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing . Management believes outcome of any resulting actions will not have a material impact on the company's consolidated financial position or results of operations .
 The defendants believe that the damages report is invalid under Illinois law and on that basis have filed a motion to exclude the expert from offering an opinion at trial . Given the uncertainty of factors that may potentially affect the resolution of the matter, at this time the company is unable to estimate the reasonably possible loss or range of reasonably possible losses in the unlikely event it were found to be liable .
 CME and SGX maintain a mutual offset agreement with a current term through May 2025 . Agreement enables market participants to open a futures position on one exchange and liquidate it on the other . Agreement will automatically renew for a one-year period after May 2025 unless either party provides advance notice of its intent to terminate .
 Farmers and ranchers eligible for up to $.25,000 per participant . Farming and ranching cooperatives eligible for $.100.0 per cooperative . CME Group has about 4.6 million shares of Series G Non-Voting Convertible Preferred Stock (Series G preferred stock) outstanding . The company believes that its guarantee liability is nominal and therefore has not recorded any liability at December 31, 2024 .
 Series G preferred stock ranks on a parity basis with the Class A common stock with respect to dividend and liquidation rights . Members of CME, CBOT, NYMEX and COMEX own or lease trading rights which entitle them access to open outcry trading, discounts on trading fees and the right to vote on certain matters as provided for by the rules of the particular exchange .
 Each class of CME Group Class B common stock has the following number of votes on matters relating to core rights: Class B-1, six votes per share; Class B 2, 1/6th of one vote per share . Holders of shares of Class A common stock do not have the right to vote on changes to the core rights .
 CME Group has adopted an Omnibus Stock Plan under which stock-based awards may be made to employees . A total of 40.2 million Class A common stock shares have been reserved for awards under the plan . The Board of Directors approved a share repurchase program in December 2024, which authorizes the company to repurchase up to $3.0 billion .
 CME Group adopted an Omnibus Stock Plan under which stock-based awards may be made to employees . Awards granted generally vest over a four-year period, with 25.9 million shares outstanding or have been exercised under the plan as of December 31, 2024 . The share repurchase program has no expiration date and does not obligate CME to acquire any particular amount of Class A common stock .
 Restricted common stock and restricted stock units generally have a vesting period of two to four years . In 2024, the company also granted 129,381% performance shares . The fair value related to these grants was $77.7.7%, which is recognized as compensation expense . The total fair value of restricted stock, restricted stock . units and performance shares that vested during 2024, 2023 and 2022 was $61.4% .
 In 2024, 2023 and 2022, employees receive an annual award of Class A common stock with a value equal to $145,000 . Non-executive directors could elect to receive some or all of the cash portion of their annual stipend in shares of stock based on the closing price at the date of distribution . Expense of $3.6.6 million related to these stock-based payments was recognized for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023 .
 The company uses a three-level classification hierarchy of fair value measurements for disclosure purposes . The company has three levels: "Primateregen" and "Princeregen," "princeregan" "Princespireregen", "princeship," "pioneering," "championship" "Pioneering" "Championed" by the company .
 The company's level 1 assets generally include investments in publicly traded mutual funds, equity securities and corporate debt securities with quoted market prices . The company’s level 2 assets and liabilities generally consist of long-term debt notes . The fair values of the long term debt notes were based on quoted market values in an inactive market .
 The company's business is conducted through one reportable business segment, CME Group consolidated . The company has one operating segment as this is the level at which resource allocation and operating decisions regarding company performance are evaluated and determined by the senior lead lead . The fair value measurements of these investments are considered level 3 and non-recurring. This investment is included in other assets on the consolidated balance sheet.
 The company’s chief operating decision maker (CODM) is the senior leadership team that includes the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer . The CODM reviews the financial results of CME Group consolidated on an ongoing basis throughout the year . Segment assets are not reported to, or used by, the CMDM to allocate resources or to assess performance .
 The company uses the two-class method to calculate basic and diluted earnings per common share . Series G preferred stock receives a proportionate allocation of undistributed or overdistributed earnings for the period . The level of financial information provided to the CODM is consistent with the financial statement line items as disclosed in our consolidated statements of income .
 The company has evaluated the effectiveness of our disclosure controls and procedures as of the end of the period covered by this Annual Report on Form 10-K. The company determined that there were no subsequent events that require disclosure . The company's net income is $3,525.8 per share . CME Group's net earnings are $3.525.2 per share and $2,691.0 per share for the years presented .
 Management evaluated the effectiveness of the company’s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024 . Management based its assessment on criteria for effective internal control of financial reporting described in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework). Management’‘Our internal control system has been designed to provide reasonable assurance to management and the board of directors .
 The effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024 has been audited by Ernst & Young LLP (PCAOB ID                 42), an independent registered public accounting firm, as stated in the report on page 87 . Management believes that, as of Dec. 31, 2024, our internal control over financial reporting is effective . In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company .
 These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company’s management . We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB . Our audits included performing procedures to assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to error or fraud . We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion .
 The Company had unrecognized income tax benefits of $251.6 million related to uncertain tax positions as of December 31, 2024 . The Company uses significant judgment to (1) determine whether, based on the technical merits, the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained upon examination and (2) measure the amount of the tax benefit that qualifies for recognition .
 Ernst & Young LLP has served as the Company’s auditor since 2002 . In our opinion, CME Group Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company) maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024, based on the criteria established in Internal Control—Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission .
 Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists . We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion . We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws .
 A company’s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company . Internal control may not prevent or detect misstatements, and projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies may deteriorate .
 In accordance with SEC rules and regulations, copies of these codes of conduct are available on our website at www.cmegroup.com . In addition, we have adopted Corporate Governance Principles which govern the practices of our board of directors . Our insider trading policy is filed as Exhibit 19.1 to this Form 10-K .
